Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Microbially Mediated Alteration of Volcanic Glass using McMurdo Extreme Environments as Natural Laboratories
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies the microbial processes that alter volcanic glass, which is critical to understanding the earliest life on earth. To understand the environmental controls on these processes, this project uses the extreme environments of the McMurdo region of Antarctica as a natural laboratory. Volcanic glass substrates are placed in hydrothermal systems, lakes, and other areas for two to four years to identify colonizing microbial consortia and the chemical processes of microbe-glass interaction. Recovered experiments are analyzed to explore the role of eukaryotic and prokaryotic organisms, and the relevance of autotrophs during colonization and biofilm formation using microscopic, molecular and culture techniques.

The broader impacts include graduate and undergraduate student participation in research and K-12 outreach and teacher training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The extreme environments of the McMurdo area offer a great variety of very different biological, chemical and physical boundary conditions that influence the characteristics of microbe-glass interaction.  We argued that organics-poor environments in hydrothermal sites around Mt Erebus, Ross Island, the near shore environments at Cape Evans, and the Dry Valleys are particularly interesting to explore autotrophs, in spatially very close settings that range from hot to extremely cold, dark to light, saline to fresh water, and in environments that also include organics-rich environments such as the Dry Valleys lakes. This study will illuminate a key aspect of the McMurdo region, where volcanism is an integral part of its geological heritage of its setting in the West Antarctic Rift. Most importantly, however, this work will help us understand how diverse environments may control a process that is globally relevant, in terms of geochemical fluxes, early earth biogeosciences and possibly in terms of total biomass. We established in situ incubation sites in the upper Taylor Valley, Lake Fryxell, at the terminus of Warren Glacier, at Evan’s Wall, inside Tramway warm soil area on Mt Erebus, and three ice caves.  We carried out two and four year exposure experiments in all of these locations except, the upper Taylor site because it was completely frozen in after the two-year experiment, Warren Cave had only a two-year experiment because we could not access it in the first year and Hubert’s nightmare that was collapsed and inaccessible after the four – year experiment.  We also collected environmental samples for six more caves, in particular to explore their fungal communities for an environmental assessment. For all sites we collected environmental samples as well as the incubation experiments, and all samples were archived and preserved, currently housed at OHSU. We identified several fumarolic Ice caves on Antarctica’s Mt. Erebus as dark oligotrophic volcanic ecosystems (DOVEs) providing a deep biosphere habitat that can provide insight into microbial communities that utilize energy sources other than photosynthesis.

The microbial communities in the ice caves are composed of Bacteria and Fungi. There is a remarkable diversity of ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RubisCO) genes, including new deeply branching Form I clades, suggesting that the Calvin cycle is a major pathway of CO2 fixation in these caves. These ecosystems appear to be extremely oligotrophic with which the majority of energy for chemoautotrophs is derived from reduced inorganic energy sources. In one cave (Warren), we identified sixty-one species of fungi soil clone libraries, with a species diversity greater than has been found in the nearby McMurdo Dry Valleys oligotrophic soil.

Fungal results suggested that at least some of these caves have been contaminated by DNA from human-induced contamination, including clones representing the Malassezia species (37% of Basidomycota identified). These fungi are associated with skin surfaces of animals and require high lipid content for growth.  In addition, we found evidence of plant residues likely introduced into the cave. This result led to a systematic study of this type of contamination in ice caves on Erebus, as well  as a new initiative to define an access policy to these caves.

We also explored the potential for contamination of eukaryotic organisms (454 analysis using eukaryotic ITS primers) for nine sites in 8 caves and found two caves seriously contaminated (Sauna and Helo), three moderately (hut, mammoth, Kachina) one minor (Heroine), and one uncontaminated (Worm Tongue).  Warren cave displayed one site that was pristine and one that had minor contamination.
